title: 105_hr1419
content: The Act titled "Child Abuse and Neglect Enforcement Act" allows certain state child protective workers and child welfare workers access to criminal conviction record information. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to require states to have a law allowing law enforcement agencies to provide criminal conviction record information to child protective and welfare workers, or face a 10% reduction in funds. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to require states to provide criminal conviction record information to child protective and welfare workers. Funds will be redistributed to participating states with such laws in effect, and the Attorney General will issue regulations for compliance. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to require states to provide criminal conviction record information to child protective and welfare workers. Amendments made by subsection (a) will take effect on the first day of each fiscal year succeeding the first fiscal year beginning 2 years after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. NEONATAL CONDITIONS CAUSED BY MATERNAL SUBSTANCE ABUSE; AMENDMENT TO PROGRAM OF BLOCK GRANTS TO STATES FOR PREVENTION AND TREATMENT OF SUBSTANCE ABUSE. Subpart II of part B of title XIX of the Public Health Service Act is amended by inserting after section 1926 the following section: "SEC. 1926A. STATE LAW REGARDING NOTIFICATION OF STATE OR LOCAL CHILD-PROTECTION AGENCY IN EVENT OF NEONATAL CONDITION CAUSED BY MATERNAL SUBSTANCE ABUSE." For fiscal year 1999 and subsequent years, the Secretary may grant funds under section 1921 if the State mandates testing newborns for drug dependence, fetal alcohol syndrome, and drug presence. Positive test results must be reported to the child protection agency. Some States have delayed implementation due to legislative sessions. For fiscal year 1999 and beyond, states must test newborns for drug dependence, fetal alcohol syndrome, and drug presence to receive grants under section 1921. Noncompliance results in a reduction of grant allotment by 10 percent. For fiscal year 1999 and beyond, states must test newborns for drug dependence, fetal alcohol syndrome, and drug presence to receive grants under section 1921. The percentage of the grant amount determined under section 1933 for the State increases over the first three fiscal years following the applicable fiscal year, starting at 20 percent and increasing to 40 percent. The term 'first applicable fiscal year' is defined as fiscal year 2000 for certain states and fiscal year 1999 for others. The Byrne Grant Program will now include enforcing child abuse and neglect laws. The Victims of Crime Act will increase the set-aside for child abuse victims from $10,000,000 to $20,000,000. A study and report will be conducted on reporting requirements under child abuse and neglect laws. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on reporting requirements under the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act and part E of title IV of the Social Security Act. A report containing the study results will be submitted to Congress and the Secretary of Health and Human Services within 6 months. The Comptroller General will submit a report on reducing reporting requirements under the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act and part E of title IV of the Social Security Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will analyze the report and provide recommendations within 90 days. After receiving the report from the Comptroller General, the Secretary of Health and Human Services will submit an analysis to Congress. The Congress acknowledges the importance of child advocacy centers in assisting victims of abuse and intervening in dangerous situations, supporting increased funding for these centers under the Victims of Child Abuse Act of 1990.
